replies.body: Please bring back tribunal. Help fix the social aspect of league trolling and inting.

Spot on.
The community would let racist and homophobic slurs slide non-stop....."FOR THE LULS BRUH!"
So yeah, no.
I'm glad it's Riot doing it because at least I know if someone finds it necessary to spam the n-word all game, that they'll get instantly suspended for two weeks, or even permabanned if it's their 2nd or 3rd offense, if i report them.
With a community council they'd get nothing, or a slap on the wrist over and over and over again.

I'm gonna call bullshit on this right here. I have reported people for being racist in game, and I have kept tabs on them and they have been playing non stop since the report. I have also sent screen shots to Riot and Riot Support on twitter, and yet they are still there. Meanwhile, when the Tribunal was up, I was constantly getting feedback from all the people that I had helped get banned. We have to police ourselves, because the people that should be policing the community are more or less not doing their job all the time.

Same. I remember a garen who spammed N word all game in ally and all chat for literally no reason and me and my duo both reported him and nothing happened. Riot likes to talk a big game about how they're against hate speech, but they don't actually practice it at all.

We say that, but I guess we forget how ineffective Tribunal was. People would often go unpunished for months due to lack of player participation creating an enormous backlog, especially toward the end of its lifespan. Rewards were also tied to the system, so people who didn't give a crap but wanted the quick rewards would go into Tribunal and spam "Pardon/Punish" just for the rewards without caring about the context of the game or the chat logs. 

Unless they rework the system from the ground up, it'd just be removed in short order again regardless of how good people think it was while it's not here. It was removed for a reason, a list of them in fact.

> We say that, but I guess we forget how ineffective Tribunal was. People would often go unpunished for months due to lack of player participation creating an enormous backlog, especially toward the end of its lifespan. Rewards were also tied to the system, so people who didn't give a crap but wanted the quick rewards would go into Tribunal and spam "Pardon/Punish" just for the rewards without caring about the context of the game or the chat logs. 
> 
> Unless they rework the system from the ground up, it'd just be removed in short order again regardless of how good people think it was while it's not here. It was removed for a reason, a list of them in fact.

Tribunal only slowed down after it removed rewards and removed the button from the home page of the site.  Riot basically relegated the feature to die removing the incentive and hiding it from newer players who weren't aware of it.

The reward system was a problem, since you could meet the minimum accuracy by just spamming "Punish" each time.  There was no effort to thwart this other than removing reward incentive.  They didn't track how much time was spent on the page, they didn't track actions being used to filter through games, they never put reports through that were meant to be Pardoned to check if people were paying attention, they went straight at the incentive system instead of making an effort to pull out the bad actors.

Removing incentive from anything through is a garbage idea.  I know Twisted Treeline and Dominion have been failing before they got removed, but intentionally excluding them from events basically punishes people who like the mode.  When your time can be spent doing something that will reward you vs something that gives you nothing, why would you do the latter unless you really, really loved it?

Really the thing isn't perfect but acting like its a failure just because of the concept is incredibly dishonest and the people who talk about how Tribunal failed rarely put into context how Riot effectively buried the thing.

The Tribunal actually look the situation into effect. If 4 players were trolling you, harassing you, and feeding then people could see it. The automated system doesn't do that and Player Support doesn't care. They only care what you did. You can literally be chat restricted for essentially nothing.

One Player Support person said that in 3+ years of working at Riot they had not ONCE reverted an automated chat restriction. You'd think there would definitely be false positives in 3+ years...

I agree with this. The automated system bans people for saying a cuss word. It can be as harmless as "Shit". if someone is trolling and reports you. The automated system doesn't read convos. It scans for keywords and bans. I have been victim of this. When I was banned for calling someone annoying. That person reported me and the automated system sent a chat dialogue of what was said. The only thing in that dialogue was calling a player annoying. Then muting them.  It resulted in a 10 game chat ban.

I’ve seen friends be banned for some truly pointless comments. I’ve also seen players that have done far worse escape with no punishment. My friend has been banned for saying and I quote “you’re living in a different reality if you think Renekton is OP” I’ve been banned for telling a Zoe who was legit intentionally feeding to “shut up and play the game instead of whining in all chat”. Frankly I really don’t care about words in a game that’s what the mute function is for. Outside of racial and homophobic slurs people shouldn’t be banned for things they say. Too often people abuse reports to ban people that they want banned because they lost in lane. The fact of the matter is the current system doesn’t work and is pseudo random in how it operates.

Only people who haven't actually participated in the Tribunal, don't know why Riot never brought it back. I've had the report accuracy of 98% and i've been there judging games on a daily basis, up to my daily limit imposed by the Tribunal itself. At one point, i've taken notice that started judging reports that were months old, which means that there existed a bottleneck where there wasn't enough people doing the work or people just spammed reports left and right and there wasn't enough people to keep up the pace.

All in all, many people literally never bothered doing this when Riot axed the IP rewards per correct case because people were just pressing "Punish" in order to expedite the free IP process and were correct the majority of the time because everyone else did the same.

The Tribunal wasn't accurate and letting others police themselves had very big downsides. That's why it was replaced by an automated system that can keep up pace with the reports and remain consistent in the verdicts.

That being said, if the system is struggling to catch some cases of "under the radar" griefing, these cases can easily be sent to the players via the trimmed down Tribunal and left for the masses to judge - according to their language and all. This feedback can then be used to train the system to better recognize these griefing attempts.
I mean... I've got nothing else to do.

That's a lot of work on Riot's end to re-invent the Tribunal and somehow I see it working out long term for the game to have a system that allows the community to help police the apes for a meager BE reward or some RP - honestly I think if Riot rewarded players with like 40RP per case and they can only take on a maximum of 20 cases per patch (5 max per day), that would be good. They'd probably gate it behind honor levels to prevent people using the system vengefully.
